extendedIngredients.name: garlic cloves
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 large garlic cloves, unpeeled1 small white onion, finely chopped

extendedIngredients.name: serrano chiles
extendedIngredients.originalString: fresh serrano chiles to taste (roughly 5, about 1 ounce total)

extendedIngredients.name: tomatillo salsa
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2/3 cup of the Essential Roasted Tomatillo-Serrano Salsa, plus more for serving

extendedIngredients.name: tomatillos
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 pound (10 to 12 medium) tomatillos, husked and rinsed

recipes.title: Cookbook of the Month – Essential Roasted Tomatillo-Serrano Salsa

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Noir, Riesling, and Sparkling rosé are my top picks for Salsa. Acidic white wines like riesling or low-tannin reds like pinot noir can work well with Mexican dishes. Sparkling rosé is a safe pairing too. One wine you could try is J Vineyards & Winery Pinot Noir. It has 5 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 48 dollars.

productMatches.title: J Vineyards & Winery Pinot Noir
productMatches.description: At J, we are devoted to the concept of terroir in the Russian River Valley, and our 2013 J Vineyards Pinot Noir is a reflection of this vintage, the vineyards and our attention to detail in the winery. Delivering bright berry flavors-red cherry, raspberry and blackberry- this elegant Pinot is enhanced by notes of licorice and red tea, which linger on the finish. Aromas of wild strawberries and spices delight the nose.

recipes.instructions: Lay tomatillos on a baking sheet and place 4 inches below a very hot broiler. When the tomatillos blister, blacken and soften on one side, about 5 minutes, turn them over and roast the other side. Cool.Roast the chiles and garlic in a heavy skillet over medium heat, turning occasionally, until blackened in spots and soft, 5 to 10 minutes for the chiles, about 15 for the garlic. Cool, then pull the stems from the chiles and peel the garlic.Combine the tomatillos, chiles and garlic in a food processor. Process to a coarse puree. Transfer to a medium-size bowl. Scoop the onion into a strainer, rinse under cold water, shake off excess and stir into the tomatillo mixture along with the cilantro.------------------------from Rick Bayless' Mexican KitchenBeat the eggs with the cream and the salt. Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium high heat, then add the mushrooms. Stir-fry until thoroughly wilted, then stir in the salsa. Continue to stir until the salsa is reduced and thick. Stir in the eggs, then stir every 10 to 15 seconds until the eggs are done to your liking. Divide onto warm plates, spoon a little more salsa and sprinkle with the cilantro and queso fresco.--------------------From Rick Bayless' Mexican Kitchen

steps.step: Lay tomatillos on a baking sheet and place 4 inches below a very hot broiler. When the tomatillos blister, blacken and soften on one side, about 5 minutes, turn them over and roast the other side. Cool.Roast the chiles and garlic in a heavy skillet over medium heat, turning occasionally, until blackened in spots and soft, 5 to 10 minutes for the chiles, about 15 for the garlic. Cool, then pull the stems from the chiles and peel the garlic.
Combine the tomatillos, chiles and garlic in a food processor. Process to a coarse puree.

Transfer to a medium-size bowl. Scoop the onion into a strainer, rinse under cold water, shake off excess and stir into the tomatillo mixture along with the cilantro.------------------------from Rick Bayless' Mexican Kitchen
Beat the eggs with the cream and the salt.

Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium high heat, then add the mushrooms. Stir-fry until thoroughly wilted, then stir in the salsa. Continue to stir until the salsa is reduced and thick. Stir in the eggs, then stir every 10 to 15 seconds until the eggs are done to your liking. Divide onto warm plates, spoon a little more salsa and sprinkle with the cilantro and queso fresco.--------------------From Rick Bayless' Mexican Kitchen
